results.headline: This Time the Dream’s on Me

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inception

results.summary_short: In Christopher Nolan’s “Inception” a specialist in corporate mental espionage and his co-workers penetrate the minds of their slumbering targets.

results.headline: When a Dweeb Learns He’s Magic

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sorcerer's Apprentice

results.summary_short: Nicolas Cage stars in a tale of supernatural powers, an ancient conflict and an N.Y.U. student with a crush.

results.headline: A Boy’s Slice of Paradise Is Time Alone With Dad

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alamar

results.summary_short: In “Alamar,” by Pedro González-Rubio, a boy takes the journey of a lifetime with his Mexican father.

results.headline: Meet the Sperm Donor: Modern Family Ties

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kids Are All Right

results.summary_short: In Lisa Cholodenko’s movie, teenagers and their two moms have dinner, and lots more, with a newly found biological father.

results.headline: He’s Off to Join the Circus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Around a Small Mountain

results.summary_short: Jacques Rivette’s “Around a Small Mountain” is as transporting and graceful as a ride in a balloon.

results.headline: Revisiting the Irascible RV Pitchman Who Went Viral

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winnebago Man

results.summary_short: Ben Steinbauer’s “Winnebago Man” documents a search for Jack Rebney, a retired RV salesman and Internet sensation.

results.headline: Tough Time for Zombie Bait

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of REC 2

results.summary_short: In “[REC]2” Jaume Balagueró and Paco Plaza follow a paramilitary team in Barcelona.

results.headline: Like Shooting Humans in a Jungly Alien Barrel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Predators

results.summary_short: Nimrod Antal’s “Predators,” a spinoff of John McTiernan’s 1987 “Predator,” is less karmic morality tale than pulpy cartoon.

results.headline: Even in the Rising Heat, She Stays Pretty Cool
results.display_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl Who Played with Fire

results.summary_short: Noomi Rapace brings an intense rightness to the role of Lisbeth Salander in “The Girl Who Played With Fire.”

results.headline: Lunar Toons and Cookie Capers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Despicable Me

results.summary_short: “Despicable Me,” the 3-D animated feature, relies on the funny voices of TV and movie actors like Steve Carell, who plays a grumpy trying to steal the Moon.

results.headline: Inspiration Through Movement

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Only When I Dance

results.summary_short: “Only When I Dance” tracks the progress of two students with professional aspirations at the Centro de Dança ballet school in Rio de Janeiro.

results.headline: Filmmakers Get Personal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Great Directors

results.summary_short: This documentary from Angela Ismailos chronicles her globe-trotting goal of interviewing 10 of her personal cinematic heroes.

results.headline: Floating Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beautiful Islands

results.summary_short: “Beautiful Islands” captures the effects of global warming on the inhabitants of imperiled islands.

results.headline: Mastering the Elements

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Airbender

results.summary_short: “The Last Airbender” can serve as a reminder of how difficult it can be to inaugurate a fantasy-action franchise.

results.headline: Global Warming Among the Undead

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Twilight Saga: Eclipse

results.summary_short: “Eclipse” elevates the love triangle’s intensity, and also nudges Bella’s somewhat abstract longings in the direction of physical lust.

results.headline: Attraction and Possibility When Sex Is Just Business

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Ranch

results.summary_short: Helen Mirren plays a madam in “Love Ranch,” a film directed by her husband, Taylor Hackford.

results.headline: A Rock ’n’ Roll Napoleon in Exile in a No-Holds-Barred Interview
results.display_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector

results.summary_short: In “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector,” the music producer compares himself to Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Bach and Galileo.

results.headline: Revenge on the Bully, Silently, in Japan

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Umarete Wa Mita Keredo

results.summary_short: Yasujiro Ozu’s “I Was Born, but...” is one of those silent black-and-white old movies that makes the subsequent advances in the medium look redundant.

results.headline: Anarchic Imagination vs. Humdrum

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Grass

results.summary_short: Alain Resnais’s romantic comedy “Wild Grass” has a heightened visual intensity and a tantalizing sense of mystery.

results.headline: Battle Company: Loving Life, Making War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Restrepo

results.summary_short: The documentary “Restrepo,” which follows a company of American soldiers in Afghanistan, has the spare, lyrical force of an elegy.
